author: oaklandmatt
content:
If you're trying to be a highly successful professional, you should do all of these things and be prepared to adjust on the fly.

I pretty much always have full songs, tracks, hooks, and concepts prepared. Much of the time, you won't use any of them on any given day. But good news: they're useful for future days.

I've had all of that prepared and then the artist and I just chat for five hours, then write a song on a piano.

I've had all that prepared and then cut song after song because the artist goes "what else do you have???"

Anecdote that might be helpful: I've been in with an artist all week. Me, another producer/writer, and her. The other producer/writer has his rig set up and he also writes topline. We usually bounce back and forth depending on what the song requires. We've all worked together before and we had the whole week blocked out so there's no pressure to perform on day one. But we did three songs on the first day because she just came in firing. The first song she came in with a title and we worked from scratch and knocked it out in an hour. The other producer made the track quick with some existing drum loops he had prepped for her, adding keys and horns as we wrote. Then she asked "do you have anything to play?" I played her a track hook I had prepared. She liked it and we powered through that one in another hour. Then we broke for lunch. We caught up. As we were finishing she mentioned this one kinda stupid and sassy idea she tried to bring into another session but the producers didn't like it. So we wrote that one and it was fire. I tapped out a tempo as she rapped the hook idea and just make a skeleton beat on the fly.

Being way over prepared is rarely going to hurt you.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I have a different angle you could try. I would focus almost all your energy on becoming a better, more truthful, richer lyricist. That's the only place you'll be original because there's only one you. Paradoxically, it's also the way you'll write songs that have a universal appeal because the more personal you get, the more the underlying universal emotions will resonate with people.

Trying to be analytical about melodies and structure and style when writing has never yielded good songs for me or literally anyone I know. All the best songwriters I've met write all their best songs lyrics first.

Also, when you have something to say, it's surprising how little you pay attention to the melody. The melodies and structural components seem to just come when your heart is already in the story.

The only other thing I'd say is learn A+ songs. Learn the lyrics completely and learn the story behind them as much as possible. Then learn to sing them the way the original version is sung. That will expand your vocabulary as a vocalist and reinforce great lyrics.

Lastly, technology is going to continue to increasingly replace stylistic innovation. Yeah AI blah blah blah, but already drum machines and synth presets and splice and DAWs. The last thing to be replaced will be you personally writing things from your experience. Songs about your deepest insecurities and songs about your pet gerbil both fall into this category. Explore all of it.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Some songwriting-related morning routine thoughts:

I've been starting my day with doing piano scales and vocal warm ups to a metronome and then singing/ learning a song and recording a voice note of it. (recently it's been Tom Petty Wildflowers at the piano). Then I look at my phone and start my day.

Hard to know for sure if it's causal, but my songwriting abilities have sped up. I'm quicker in sessions, both with topline and tracks. 

I think it's related to several aspects of the morning routine, and they all compound. 

*I'm playing music before I'm on my phone, so I'm outputting music before my brain starts reacting.

*doing scales w piano and voice opens up my vocabulary on both instruments and makes me much more comfortable to sing/play ideas when writing
*doing these to a metronome has improved my timing on all instruments (not just piano and vocal)
*learning a great song and singing it every morning has massively improved my lyrical writing/ improvisation (probably the hardest part of songwriting) by just reinforcing good *sounding* words.
*singing and recording the same song every morning for a few days or a week makes me really THINK about vocals and vocal production. How I'm singing the words, how to push certain vowels in a certain part of my voice, etc

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes exactly! I've found that the best songs are never calculated, they're always just felt as they're being created. They are magical/ incalculable moments. As soon as people start analyzing – "is this too generic?" "maybe we should have a part like **insert artist**" – the songs loses its magic.

But the paradox is that you can't  just sit around and wait for them to happen. You have to be in motion. So often times building habits and processes (which are calculated) is a great way to keep oneself in the motion of creating things. Piano scales, learning songs, writing a song a day, etc., are just some of the many ways to do this.

And the other aspect is also correct. These are skill building exercises that help the quick translation of creative ideas. It's the emotional and psychological side of workflow. Just like technical workflow – where you want the shortest time between idea an execution – same goes for writing. If you are constantly writing lyrics and singing melodies and playing instruments, when that emotional magical idea arrives, you can translate it more quickly into lyrics, melody, and music.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I always tailor it to the artist in some way. It's a combination of making fresh ideas specifically for them and taking existing ideas that could work (sometimes reworking existing ideas). I never go into a session like an actual blind date where I don't know anything about them.

The challenge is always do I make something that sounds like what they've done, or do I make something that sounds like where they're going? That's impossible to answer. I've had success in major label POP artist sessions by having a 100 year old piano and specifically not playing tracks. Meaning, you never know if an artist is tired of doing the same shit. Because I have confidence in my skill as a producer, I'm happy to get an A+ ballad because I know I can turn it into whatever production I want. "In The Name Of Love" is my most successful example of this. It's an emotional 3 chord piano ballad that was produced into a festival EDM anthem. 

I've had the most success being prepared for all options. Mostly because that makes me flexible for what an artist is feeling that day, but also because the more stuff I make, the more music I'm making. If I prep for a session, I'm not working cold. The prep is also like a psychological and creative warm up for me. Prep makes me a better improviser.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Just had thanksgiving dinner at Alan Burgman’s house and we talked a good amount about songwriting. If you’re not familiar with his work, he’s 98 years old and has written lyrics for everyone from Frank Sinatra to Aretha Franklin to Quincey Jones to half of the artists your grandma listened to. 

Anyways, some good takeaways from last night’s convo:

“Writers these days are more interested in immediate appeal than they are in a great song. They aren’t the same thing. A great song is only a great song if people will want to cover it in 30 years” 

He cares immensely that whatever is being said in a song is worth saying. Does the message have strong intrinsic value?  

He’s verrrry quick to say he doesn’t like a song.

He has a strong preference for melody being written before the lyrics, which is particularly interesting consider his career is as a lyric guy. 

He has a strong dislike for slant rhymes. (I disagreed and it turned into a whole family convo about phonetic tension and release)

He’s still writing every single day without fail. Today he’s writing on an upcoming Pat Metheny record. 

He’s never heard of Drake or Olivia Rodrigo. Mind you his wife was the president of ASCAP for 15 years so this is particularly mind blowing. It shows me how siloed different worlds can be even when they are so similar and near to one another. What wisdom does one silo have on lock that the other is missing? What rules have been taught to us by people in one silo that don’t apply in the silos we ourselves are working in? A lot to chew on here.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Ok this is one of my favorite topics ever.

Happy to go deeper, but the gist is this: I believe people connect to the underlying emotion, even if their analytical brain isn't reading or understand the lyrics. If the emotion is authentic, the song has a MUCH better chance of connecting. Without that emotion, it is almost impossible. 

The more I write songs, the older I get, the more I work with the greatest songwriters, the more I think that writing an authentic emotion is everything. 

A favorite example (I have 100 more, just ask): 

Party In The USA. Silly pop song? Or deep truth about the power of music being able to transcend loneliness? Go into the lyric and you realize it's Jessie J writing about her first time coming to Los Angeles: 

Stepped off the plane at LAX with a dream and a cardigan... am I gonna fit in... everybody looks so famous... I'm feeling homesick, too much pressure and I'm nervous... but then my favorite song comes on the radio... I know I'm gonna be ok... it's a party in the USA"

Tbh I tear up every time I think about this song. Yeah people might not analyze the lyric, but the reason this song will play for the next 50 years (and not the 1mil other simple songs about having a party) is the deep, authentic, universal emotion underlying the record.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I'll give a point by point analysis, cuz why not?

First off, I love Irving Berlin. One of the greatest ever. White Christmas, God Bless America, Always, Cheek to Cheek. A master of the craft. 

That being said, adhering to portions of this list could lead a songwriter in 2024 exactly in the wrong direction. Keep in mind two things: one, great artists are rarely great explainers of what makes them great. And two, his career ended in the late 1950s. This means his golden era was pre-Motown, pre-Beates, pre-television, etc.

Ok, my thoughts:

1. This doesn't apply any more. He's speaking in relation to a time when music was more complicated. Music is MUCH simpler now. For example, White Christmas has a much larger vocal range than every Selena Gomez song. Also, 99% of songs today are recorded by someone writing it. It's much more important for the singer/songwriter to sing the song in their vocal range than to worry about some future audience. People rarely write songs and then hire a demo singer any more.

2. (and 7 and 8) The best advice on here. Simplify. "Kill your children." Remove things you love in order to make the song more concise.

3. No. The culture changed, there are a million counter examples since Motown/Beatles. Sure, you can write a song without gender ("you"), but saying songs SHOULD be genderless is just wrong.

4. Don't write frivolous songs? I'm all about authenticity and connecting emotionally to a song, but this is strangely phrased and doesn't seem very instructive. 

5. Every time I've seen people try and follow this, they write bad songs. As the great David Foster said "There are only 12 notes and 26 letters, and Beethoven and Shakespeare already did it better than you." You're unlikely to find original chords, melodies, or words. The only original thing is your own life experience. Don't be "original," be honest.

6. Kinda. I guess I mostly stick to this. But also, there are thousands of great counterexamples after 1960.

7, 8, 9. All great

author: Zakhiggins
content:
1. I do it first thing in the morning when I wake up before things like my phone ruin my brain for the day. 

2. Make it a routine. I make some time before i have to go anywhere every morning to try and create something. When your brain gets used to the idea that you're going to that place at the same time every day, once you go there then the ideas flow better with time.

3. Understand it's ok to write something bad, with time good ones come. 

4. Understand that a song is never actually finished, it can only be abandoned wherever you chose to abandon it.

4.5. Understand that it's ok to figure out what a song means after you write it.

5. Understand that we're trying to make trees, not tables. (As in sometimes it's not healthy to keep refining something till it's too straight edge and the vitality is gone from it)

6. Said it already but saying it again, don't check your phone before you write

7. I don't always write lyrics. Sometimes i write a melody, sometimes a chord progression, sometimes lyrics. Every now and then i do a session of what i call Lego writing, where i try to see what lyrics i wrote before fit with what melody/chord progression etc. 

8. Oh and did i mention, it ruins my creativity to check my phone before i make anything? 

This is what works for me, hope it helps you!

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Outside of just getting daily reps, the main goal of this particular practice (the 30 minute write) is that you're setting parameters where you don't have time to decide if something is good. The point is to relieve yourself of any editing and force yourself to quickly write lyrics and melodies. 

It's doing two separate and important things: building muscle memory and teaching to work on instinct.

Building songwriting muscle memory is just like learning a language. You're practicing over and over until you learn how to express yourself emotionally. This is the basics component. You'll learn what notes you can hit and what words rhyme and how rhythms bounce. You'll build a foundation that will become second nature.

Related but distinct, you will learn how to move quickly. It turns out most great songs come in an unthinking way. Until you learn how to write without editing and thinking about what you're doing, you are less likely to write those great songs.

I'm speaking from a lot of personal experience, but also whether it's Hemmingway's "write drunk edit sober," or the Rick Rubin, Pharrell, etc. belief that great songs come from some power outside of ourselves ("Source" or God or whatever), learning to create without being analytical is super super important.

"Pretend that you are two quarreling lovers"
"Pretend you are a human and you are currently on fire."
"Pretend that you are a statue watching people pass by. What would you see?"
"Generate a list of nonsense words that sound plausible."

author: Slow Hand
content:
I've always been inspired by the working relationship between Elton John and Bernie Taupin. 

Bernie (who strictly writes lyrics) would mail completed lyrics to Elton, who would sit at the piano and write to them. I can see several advantages  here:

A) You have a complete subject, theme, and narrative arc.

B) The dramatic arc of the lyric informs the shape of the music, which can give the lyric additional support and also shake the writer out of their usual approach.

C) The lyric can be stretched or compressed until it finds it's proper cadence and allow the singer (Elton) to find the best melodic fit to support the lyrics.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
You're absolutely right that trying to copy existing hits rarely makes great songs. He's 100% correct on that point.

I'm saying that songwriters often fall into the trap of trying to be "original." They mistakenly think this means they should try to invent new phrases or not use "generic" words or try to do something "interesting" with the chords. Instead of doing the only original thing that is possible which is tell your story and express your taste. This is actually much more difficult to do because it's incredibly vulnerable.

You can compose fully original compositions this way. But it's also interesting how much groundbreaking music comes from direct appropriation of existing popular music. 

From folk music ("Blowin In The Wind" is a melody from another song) to hip hop (all of sampling) to producers and DJs making careers from remixes, playing around with current or past hits can also yield incredible new music.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
You're way overthinking it and trying to find some "solutions."

The only thing that important is writing A LOT of songs. The only thing. Only. Yes. Only.

Why? Because forced reps is the only way to learn the language of songwriting. You need to practice over and over to get the muscle memory of writing. It's like the language of an instrument or a literal spoken language.

Any books, tips, videos, classes, spiritual paths, etc etc are only useful right now if they get you to write MORE. But really, you do not need them. I strongly disagree with anyone who says otherwise.

FWIW, my 25 years, billions of streams, platinum hit songs, blah blah has taught me that reps are the ONLY foundation. The best songwriters write all the time and didn't really get good until they'd written hundreds to thousands of songs.

@Zack Hames is on the right track. But don't "attempt" to write a song a day. Force yourself to do it. Immerse like you would learning a language. Don't wait to express yourself perfectly, start writing songs like a five-year-old and work your way up. 

Unlike mixing where you need to learn how things like compression work, or like playing guitar where it's important to have someone show you proper technique, you cannot learn how to be a great songwriter by anything other than doing it over and over*.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
This is a little of the top of my head, but I'll try and break it down like this. You're mostly going to get work/ collaborators for three reasons. 

The #1 is your work (great songs, in this case). If you make great shit, people will either hear it and reach out, or when you meet someone, you'll send each other things and they'll love your work and want to be a part of what you can do. no matter where you are in your career, this is #1 always always always. When I was starting out, I produced some of the best sounding records for local bands, so other local bands wanted to work with me. Now, I (or my manager, or my publisher) can send a spotify playlist with songs people know, and that helps get me gigs.

#2 is making shit with people you know personally. This is the best way to do it starting out since you don't have lots of great work out in the world. You need a little community of friends that you make shit with. I guess a lot of that will start moving online, but still the vast majority of great work gets done in person. #3 is the pure cold call hustle. It's TOUGH. It's a low percentage game no matter what you're trying to do (be it mixing or writing or producing or being an artist). It's not to say it doesn't have value, but if you want responses, you have to have a good pitch and sending out thousands of messages. But the other thing about this is that writing songs remotely frankly fucking sucks compared to doing it in person. Songwriting is such an in the moment emotional thing. author: Rob Domos
content:
His stance against slant rhymes seems to be more about being in favor of things fitting very tightly together and having intentionality and form and structure. He and another friend of mine viewed slant rhymes as mostly a product of laziness, as if the writer couldn’t be bothered to find something that truly fit.  

I countered referencing the hook to an Olivia Rodrigo song where every single rhyme is a slant rhyme, which IMO adds to the value of it because she’s trying to express how things don’t quite fit and how the thoughts in her mind are unresolved, and the rhyme scheme should reflect that to create a unified feeling. 

The lyrics are:

You’ve got me thinking
That two plus two equals five 
And I’m the love of your life 
Cause if rain don’t fall and sun don’t shine 
Then changing you is possible 
No, Love is never logical 

Here she’s searching and grasping. She’s unresolved. She literally uses a metaphor of the math not adding up. Why would we then make the math add up phonetically? It would weaken the effect. 

Alan was meh on it. 

I also argued that hard rhymes can be like the phonetic equivalent of a classical Haydn V-I movement that has very little color or tension, and that slight rhymes can be like jazz chords and that adding a 7 and a sharp 11 on top of the tonic chord doesn’t mean you “failed to resolve”. Someone else at the table was like “well show me a truly great song built on slant rhymes and we’ll see. I’m open to it” and in my head I was like “I thought I just did” but they didn’t love it.

author: itaylerner
content:
Man, I have so many thoughts on this! I relate on so many levels. 100% agree with everything @NoahNeedleman said.

On the more zoomed in side of things, I have found a couple things to work extremely well. 

1.) specific positive feedback. “Great take” is fine. “Wow, the way you said this specific word really resonated with me, I remember feeling that way as a kid blah blah blah blah blah.” That specific positive feedback makes people feel safe, heard, and valued. “Cool idea, let’s keep exploring” feels really dismissive and tends to make people feel like they’re in boot camp which is not fun for anyone 

2.) mirroring emotions for validation. This might be a hot take but it’s what works for me: If they’re totally stoked about it you need to be stoked too. Just as stoked. Just fake it if you need to, ~especially~ in the early writing stages. You can always go back and revisit ideas, but once someone feels like their enthusiasm and creativity and taste is being questioned, it takes forever to rebuild that trust. Mirror their emotions, get excited, be specific. THEN, once you have established the kinship and spent your own time living with the idea and better understanding what would improve it, you can bring up “hey I was thinking and I have some ideas that might be able to make what you created hit even more!”

Sometimes melody first. But mostly drums first.

Build an instrumental just chasing intuition, quickly. 2-3 melody parts and a bass line on top of drums. And youve got a chorus loop.

Im not a big humming guy, I get to words pretty quickly. But will start with common phrases to me like,  "runnin runnin runnin round runnin runnin runnin down" I have a few others.

I start to land on a melody, with a feeling and story. That I haven't told. Sometimes it takes 90 seconds, sometimes 5-10 mins. 

Record and comp till I have what I like. Than do all the background vocals. 

Then start muting a couple of the melody parts. Find my verses.

Rinse repeat the process above. But now I know the story and I just have to find the melody and the thru line narrative.

Depending on how the verses feel running into the chorus. Or short length of track. I'll write a bridge 

Melodyne the vocals.

Structure the song.

Mix the song.

Upload the song.

Make another.

This usually takes 2-4 days, intermittent with regular life.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
As I'm sure you already know , there is no such thing as enough. It's like how perfection doesn't exist. 

It may be easier to think of being a writer on a spectrum from hobbyist to full-time artist. The one end is the hobbyist who does it whenever they want and have time (other priorities take precedent). The other end is the artist who is compelled to do it and it has to turn it off in order to live a normal life.

Most people here are somewhere in between. For most of us, the key is to do a combination of two things:

1. Find every way possible at all times to joyfully write. Direct yourself toward it with how live. Write silly things for fun, have a guitar you like to play next to the place you always like to sit, write emotional things for catharsis, write with other people for the collaborative joy, sing in the shower, write on different instruments that feel inspiring, etc etc 

2. The harder part is developing habits and practices that keep you consistent. It's easy to write when it's fun. It's harder to write when it's not fun, and that's the time to make sure you're doing it. Daily practices, schedules, deadlines (self imposed or otherwise) are the best way to do this.

author: Yago Ibars
content: I've been having a thought on my songwriting I wanted to share here. As a songwriter I have this toolbox of melodic and harmonic approaches  that I can use to solve any problem when making a song, or to have direction to create another section. But recently I've been noticing that something that makes a huge impact on songs is how the different sections relate to the tempo of the track. I think this might not happen to people who write to a beat, but I think that when you are playing an instrument, tempo is so fluid that some parts of a song might "feel" good and others won't (at a same tempo). When all the sections flow well into another in terms of tempo (and probably how that affects to vocal delivery) it sucks you in as a listener and it is way more singable/enjoyable. And now I'm starting to see this as a priority more than which notes of the scale have more weight on the chorus and stuff like that.

author: Deleted User
content: I think a lot of it has to do with the melodic rhythm. In terms of how the sections flow, if the melody can drive it on its own- the accompaniment or production will follow. And as you mentioned, high notes can move the energy and accent the rhythm. Lyrical stress patterns could contribute to the accenting and note selections. Weight sometimes means notes that are held longer than the other sometimes the opposite. Contrasts can do a lot though. Range of movement or the range of the pitches themselves, pacing of the rhythm and rests, breaking the patterns/repetition can help with contrast

author: Deleted User
content: I deal with (unintentional) inconsistent tempo and some time even time signature/pulse pretty often when working with songwriters and artists. It seems to solve the problem when you tap your feet to the melody. Then you would realize that the tempo has changed. And count 1-2-3-4 or whatever the meter is. So you don’t end up unintentionally having an extra beat because of words and disrupt everything else. A lot of writers ask people for beats first for this reason, but if the melody doesn’t stand on it’s own- relying on the beats will do more harm than good in my opinion. They often end up being mediocre melodies from my experience because there’s already tons of subdivisions and grooves in the beat and the topliner is relying on that to drive the rhythmic feel. But also beats need to come in with pocket so there are space for the vocal melody to fit in. It would be good for writers to start without a beat or instrumentals and it would be good for beatmakers to practice leaving vocal pockets when starting with a beat first

So I’ve got a songwriting question, and I’ll tag @Slow Hand cause I’ve got a feeling with his teaching experience, maybe he knows (big love if you do have advice here man!) but I’ll see if I get any others with good advice here. 

Does anyone have good resources or exercises to help educate a new artist on how to write a vocal melody? She’s an incredible lyricist with a great instinct and vision, and having her in sessions has really sparked the song creation process, but she’s really struggling to learn the “theory”/musical side of vocal melody and I feel like my attempts to coach by example aren’t strengthening her knowledge or confidence.

author: Slow Hand
content:
First off, I’ll second @oaklandmatt’s recommendation that she start exposing herself to a lot of different songs, learning them, and working her writing muscles. A lot of this melodic intuition will come with time, familiarity and having a feel for what’s possible.

How is her ear? I’ve worked with plenty of great singers with little-to-no comprehension for theory. While it can help, I find that for some personality types being too technical and trying to get them to learn theory is a turnoff and is never going to happen. Where does she fit on this spectrum?

Do your best to assure her that she can open up and not be perfect right away. It sounds like she might be clamming up a little bit because she feels uncertain or unconfident. I always try to give my singers a place where they will feel comfortable throwing out any idea. Even horrible ones. It’s okay to fail or fall on your face.  Maybe she needs some reassurance in order to open up. Let her know that she doesn’t have to be perfect. Many singers do better when they have a safe space to open up and attempt new things. Even Prince would tell his engineer to leave the room every time when it became time to track his vocals. Hendrix would hide himself behind a wall of gobos where nobody could see him.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Asking for Chat GPT to replicate someone's style in any convincing way is a massive lift to ask of it. Joni's style is emotionally insightful, nuanced, and witty. Her choices are informed by a lifetime of experience and point of view. It's almost ineffable at times. It feels like magic. Poetry is elusive. Most humans can barely do it themselves at that level. Asking these programs to perform at that level is... a lot.

There's a meme that I came across recently. It was the jazz saxophonist Chris Potter describing how in order to do what he does he has to be practicing at a level that is 10x beyond what he might actually play in a session. In a sense he needs creative and technical headroom to arrive at what the result that the rest of us witness.

Some poetry follows this same principle. It's deeply, deeply ingrained and considered. The best poetry resonates and hints at things that aren't even explicitly mentioned. There's an iceberg of practice and experience beneath the surface of what we see. All Chat GPT sees is the surface. The final results that we're feeding it. It has no conception of the experiences that it's trying to replicate so it's approximations of something so complex and nuanced are likely to fall flat.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I go off the assumption that this is the only time I'll have this artist focused on this idea, so my priority is always getting a finished lead vocal and some ad libs. Those are the only things that can't be done without the artist there. I'll get the production together as much as it needs to be to get the artist excited about the song. 

The challenge is doing this quickly, without spending unnecessary time going through snares and patches and shit. I find that nearly all of the best songs I've written happen in about an hour long window of excitement. Sometimes you can stretch and get harmonies or punch in some vocals beyond that hour, but the excitement of a great idea is exhausting and it's hard to keep everyone 100% engaged for a long period of time. If I'm on hour 2 of a song and we're still trying to decide if we like a chorus, 100% of the time it's not a good song (in my experience).

A BIG mistake I make (still) is "oh we have tomorrow we can take a break and come back." It's not about being able to get the artist physically back, but getting everyone back into the emotional space. So much of what I need from an artist is the emotional focused to commit 100% to a vocal.

Once the lyrics are done and I’m working on the song, I always end up having to change a lot, usually simplify and take out, but it’s an easy problem when you have excess good lyrical content. As opposed to trying to summon something meaningful to fit a certain melody.

Simple stuff like starting with getting the chorus right has also been super helpful, and keeping production to a minimum before the topline is finished.

author: Pio

Late to this one, hope your songwriting journey is going great this past while! 

If you’re still looking for more on this, and don’t mind a little reading, I was recommended Pat Pattinson’s Write Better Lyrics years ago and I found it a super helpful tool - I loved the recommendation of a 10 min a day exercise of ‘object writing’, and also the idea of thinking about your verses as a way of ‘loading’ story and fuel for your choruses. 

Jeff Tweedy also has an even shorter but really uplifting book on writing called ‘How to Write One Song’, which is excellent. It’s more geared towards the personal, less towards industry, but I’m so convicted that writing personal songs IS the way to reach others that I would definitely recommend it too.

author: Pio
content:
And if you don’t wanna go buying books, I’d recommend possibly trying out the daily practice of object writing; you could even try it for a week or so, and you’ll end up getting interesting imagery, some of which you may be able to use in your songs - but if you stick at it a bit (I find if I do it solidly in the mornings for a week or two it just warms my brain right up for writing throughout the day) it can help get your brain into that mode, so that when you go into your writing sessions later, your brain is already making those connections. Just an option of course - everyone’s got their own way with lyric, it really is so personal. Whatever tools help, use em, whatever tools don’t, chuck em. 

I just mention these things bc you talk about making the songs ‘real’, and I feel that - I love trying to get a song to feel properly grounded, with a sense of place and reality. Best solution I’ve found is to just leave a bit of me in there - somehow it’s like people can feel when songwriting is ‘real’, so I just try to make sure my heart is in/behind each line, keep them smooth, rinse repeat
